I have the following setup within my own WiFi network: one machine (A) connected to my Wifi (which connects to the internet), and one machine (B) running Wireshark, with a Wifi adapter in monitoring mode capturing packets from A. B has already deauth A (i.e. obtaining full handshakes). And with the WiFi password, B can fully decrypt all WiFi packets in and out of A, on Wireshark. I notice that the majority of these packets are of protocol LLC, which is for UDP. Now, say I log into my Gmail on A, and send out an email with a short text message. What would be the process to capture and reassemble this text message on B? Or is this objective even possible? 

                {`#include 
#include 
#include 
int main()
{
    // Generate data
    const unsigned arraySize = 32768;
    int data[arraySize];

    for (unsigned c = 0; c < arraySize; ++c)
        data[c] = std::rand() % 256;

    // !!! With this, the next loop runs faster.
    std::sort(data, data + arraySize);

    // Test
    clock_t start = clock();
    long long sum = 0;
    for (unsigned i = 0; i < 100000; ++i)
    {
        for (unsigned c = 0; c < arraySize; ++c)
        {     // Primary loop.
            if (data[c] >= 128)
                sum += data[c];
        }
    }
    double elapsedTime = static_cast(clock()-start) / CLOCKS_PER_SEC;

    std::cout << elapsedTime << '\\n';
    std::cout << "sum = " << sum << '\\n';
}`}
